summary: new influenza virus A/H1N1 (2009) was isolated in 214 countries 1 year after first identification. a major issue was to estimate the transmissibility of the new virus. three parameters should be documented quickly in this respect. the serial interval (SI) is the time interval between the date of symptoms onset in one case and that in its infector. it is not an intrinsic property of the disease, but a combination of biology and behavior. cases may be observed in households, where common exposure may have led to coprimary cases and ongoing transmission to an overlap of secondary and tertiary cases. the serial interval (SI), i.e., the time interval between the date of symptoms onset in one case and that in its infector, is often considered instead of the GT because it has the same mean. 14 The GT or SI informs on the speed of transmission of the disease. Query Q1 reported 101 hits in MEDLINE, and query Q2 reported 75 hits in MEDLINE. the search was performed on July 28, 2010, and was limited to publications in English after April 2009. data description Method Author Modelbased estimates May 2009 April 2009 Mexico – 19 [13, 27] Epidemic in La Gloria, Mexico Mathematical modelling of the epidemic curve Fraser 34 October 2009 April–May 2009 Mexico – 27 [26–29] 32 [29–34] Dates of onset of laboratoryconfirmed cases Probabilistic modelling of the transmission chain Yang 29 February 2010 April–June 2009 Canada – 44 Laboratoryconfirmed cases of pandemic H1N1 influenza with known date of onset 58 cases with no other contact known Model fitting to empirical serial intervals, allowing tertiary cases Ghani 31 December 2009 May, 2009 USA 78 26 [22, 35] Onset dates. index cases: probable/confirmed H1N1 2009 flu reported to CDC. students in secondary school with laboratoryconfirmed infections. other cases 12 household contacts Mean of empirical serial intervals (red) or generation time (black) estimated for the A/H1N1 2009 pandemic, with 95% confidence interval. the largest estimate (44 days, range = [1,9]) was obtained from only five serial intervals observed in three households. the median SI was 35 days (CI 95% [29, 41]) 26 and 3 days (95% CI [25–35]. no correlation was found between the reported SI and the size of the study (P = 03) or the date of report (P = 03). householdbased studies did not yield different estimates of the mean SI than closecontact studies (P = 015) ten papers qualified the reproduction number as ‘basic’, with a range from 13 to 23. all assuming that the whole population was susceptible at first. this range was not significantly different from that of the otherwise reported R values. daily clinical and laboratoryconfirmed cases Maximumlikelihood estimation of R and GT based on Poisson assumption White 36 October 2009 US Mexico 10–21 [10, 37] 23 [21, 25] 35 Onset dates; P = 0004) there was a decreasing trend in the reported values with time (r = 05, P = 0004) large estimates were more frequent at first. Other cases: 16 laboratoryconfirmed contacts with no other contact known Fitting of parametric distribution to interval censored data. the number of pairs infector/infectee n is coded by the size of the symbol. in a first group of 13 studies, estimation was based on the analysis of observed time intervals between cases and their close contacts, especially in households. the largest estimate (44 days, range = [1,9]) was obtained from only five serial intervals observed in three households. only the first nonindexcase in the household was used. the mean SI was 35 days (CI 95% [29, 41]) 26 and 3 days (95% CI [25–35]. a second group of four studies reported the SI or GT by modeling epidemic curves. these included the smallest estimate of all, a mean GT of 19 days in a Mexican village, 34 and the largest, a mean GT of 4–5 days in Ontario. white estimated the mean SI at 26 days (CI 95% [19, 33]), but accounting for increased case ascertainment in time reduced this estimate to 22 days. date estimates for the A/H1N1 (2009) pandemic according to location and date of publication. for 2009, only estimates corrected for underreporting and mean GT approximately 3 days were shown. no correction was applied for an early estimate in mexico (R = 22 38 ) and another analysis (R = 23 29 ). the number of studies documenting the serial interval in the 2009 influenza pandemic contrasts with the relative absence of information for past pandemics or seasonal influenza. the current estimate for A/H1N1 (2009) was somewhat closer to the first estimate. no information was available for past pandemics. two studies used modeling to explicitly account for such phenomenon. in both approaches, the modeled mean SI was shorter than the empirical mean of observed values. this suggests that tertiary transmission is always an issue for estimating the serial interval of influenza. a third factor was underdeclaration in the initial period of the pandemic. the short mean GT (19 days 34) estimated early in Mexico may have led to underestimation when it was used to estimate the reproduction number. the initial R is the most relevant estimates as it informs on the required strength of interventions and is useful to calibrate mathematical models. the reproduction number may have been poorly estimated at the start of the pandemic, as a result of poor case ascertainment, and how imported cases were accounted for in estimation. the a/H1N1 (2009) pandemic led to less mortality than previous pandemics. serial intervals and generation times were characteristic in the first year of introduction of the virus. a second issue is that the combination of rapid transmission and limited number of contacts in households may lead to small intervals. some cases counted as secondary may have been attributed to common exposure (coprimary cases), leading to a downward bias. s of the latent and infectious period, so that the mean GT should have been 6 days instead of 4–5 days in Canada 35. the mean GT is L + 3/4 I, so it should have been 16 days rather than 19 days in the la Gloria epidemic in Mexico. a third factor was underdeclaration in the initial period of the pandemic. the short mean GT (19 days 34) estimated early in Mexico may have led to underestimation when it was used to estimate the reproduction number in later studies. the reproduction number estimates of a/H1N1 (2009) pandemic ranged from 12 to 23. this was lower than the median for 1889, 1918, and 1957, but compared with 1968. a large number of studies have documented transmission parameters for the pandemic almost in real time.
